quote: Looks like he used some sort of    encryption program to bypass the    access protocols.
Unbelievable... the nerve.
You wanted to see me, Major?
Don't pretend you don't know what    this is about.
Maybe this'll jog your memory.        Engage monitor.
Come to Quark's, Quark's is fun,    come right now, don't walk, run!
I love the part where my name    rotates around...
Tampering with the station's com-   system is a class-three offense.
It's just a little advertisement.    (when this doesn't sway     them)   I didn't put one up in Ops.
I'm sure the magistrate will take    that into consideration when he    calculates your fine.
You.
As you can see, we're very busy    here. Station business.
How did you do it?
How'd he do what?
I ordered a glass of prune juice    from a Replicator in the Defiant's    Mess Hall. This is what it came    in.
If all your little    "advertisements" aren't purged    from our systems by the time I get    back from the Gamma Quadrant...        I will come to Quark's, and    believe me, I will have fun.
Let me help you with that,    Chief...
According to Chief O'Brien the    scan resolution on the new sensors    is amazing. We could practically    do the entire bio-survey from    orbit.
Suits me. The sooner we get out of    the Gamma Quadrant the better.
(moving to stand between     them)   How can you say that?
Those little points of light out    there are the great unknown,    beckoning to us. I wish I could    visit every one.
You might want to skip the ones    with Jem'Hadar bases on them.
Is it my imagination... or are    the stars a little brighter in the    Gamma Quadrant?
Is it my imagination, or has    Julian lost his mind?
Setting course for the Gavara    system...

I'm picking up some kind of    emergency signal. It's    fragmented.       They say their homeworld's been    attacked... Massive destruction...    heavy casualties...       They're asking any passing vessel    for assistance...
Looks like the signal's coming f   rom somewhere in the Teplan    system.
That's just outside Dominion    space.
Let's hope the Jem'Hadar know    that...       Setting new course...
Let's stay in close contact. If    the Jem'Hadar come this way, we're    going to have to get out of here fast.
Acknowledged.
What happened here?
Help me...
Please... don't let me die here...    take me to Trevean...
Trevean?
Hospital...
I'll try to find out where it    is...
I'm going to give you something    for the pain...
You're not from this world.
No...
The Blight's quickened in her.    There's nothing you can do.
You should leave here. Now. Go    back to where you came from and    forget about this place.
The painkiller I gave her isn't    having much effect.    (giving her another    hypo)   These people's neurophysiology is   so different from ours, I doubt   this "blight" is any danger to us.
I got us transportation to the    hospital.
How'd you manage that? These    aren't the friendliest people I've    ever met.
This is a hospital... ?
She's quickened...
Take her to Trevean.
You're offworlders.
Yes.
Don't worry, we'll take care of    her now.
I haven't seen a single person who    doesn't have lesions on their    face...
His look inflamed... so do that    girl's over there --
Trevean...
Thank you...       For this.
You deserve nothing less...

Yesterday morning when I awoke, I    saw that it had finally    happened... I'd quickened. I    always thought I'd be afraid...       But I wasn't. Because I knew I    could come here.       Last night I slept in a bed for    the first time in my life.
This morning I bathed in hot    water... I put on clean clothes.       And now I'm here, with my family    and friends...
You're the strangers who brought    Norva here...
How is she?
It was too late for her.
If only she'd come sooner, I    could've helped her.
Then there is a treatment for the    Blight?
There is no cure. It's always    fatal.
I don't understand -- you just    said you could've helped her.
Why are you here?
We received a distress call, we're    here to help in any way we can.
I'm a doctor.
I have access to sophisticated    diagnostic equipment.
We had sophisticated equipment   once. Do you think our world was   always like this? Two centuries   ago, we were much like you. We   built great cities, traveled to   neighboring worlds...
We believed nothing was beyond our    ability. We even thought we could    resist the Dominion.

I see you've heard of them.       Then take care not to defy them...    or your people will pay the same    price we did. The Jem'Hadar    came... and left our world    crushed, as an example to others.
Bring Milani's child to me.       More than anything, the Dominion    wanted my people to bear the mark    of their defiance. And so they    gave us the Blight.

We're all born with it... and we    all die from it. The Blight    quickens... the lesions turn    red... and death comes soon    after... Some die in childhood...    most before they can have children    of their own... only a few live to    be my age.
Trevean... if you're willing to    tell us what you know about the    Blight, we might be able to help.
You should go.       If the Jem'Hadar find you here...
We're willing to take that risk.
Don't --
Give him some room...
I'm a doctor.
Leave him alone, you're ruining    everything.
Can't you see he's dying?
Of course he is. He came here to    die.
People come to me when they    quicken. I help them leave this    world peacefully, surrounded by    their family and friends.
What are you saying?
The herbs I give them cause death    within minutes...
You poison them?
The Blight kills slowly. No one    wants to suffer needlessly.        Like the woman you brought to me.
You... killed her...
I did what she asked of me.
I thought this was a hospital...    that you were a healer...
I am. I take away pain.
You disrupted Tamar's death; it    was supposed to be a very special    moment for his family. I'm going    to have to ask you to leave.

I found the distress beacon in an    abandoned building not far from    here. It has its own power    source. My guess is that it's    been repeating the same message    for the last two hundred years.
There's nothing for us to do    here... we should go...

character: A small voice from off-screen interrupts.EKORIA
quote: Are you really a doctor?
Yes.
I've never met a doctor before.
Now you have.        What do you think?

They say there's a woman in    Nykalia who makes a potion that    numbs the nerves. She gives it to    people so they can withstand the    pain of quickening and live a    little longer. But Nykalia is so    far away.
When are you due?
Not for another two months.
That's not so long...
You never know when the quickening    will come to you.
I'm Julian. What's your name?
Ekoria...
I'm Jadzia....
Did you come here to help us?
No one here seems to want our    help.
I do. And I know others who'd    welcome it, too.
Kira to Away Team.
Go ahead.
Sensors just picked up two   Jem'Hadar ships headed this way...
The Jem'Hadar are leaving the    Kendi system... looks like they're    heading for the Obatta cluster.
Sounds like they're on a patrol    route -- which means this system    is probably next.
We'd better go.       Stand by to get underway.
Hold on, Major... we can't just    leave these people. They need our    help.
And they'll get it. As soon as we    get back we'll notify Starfleet so    they can put together a relief    mission.
That could take weeks, maybe even    months. We're here now.

Do you remember the plague on    Boranis Three? People were dying    by the thousands and no one there    knew why. It took us an hour to    identify the pathogen, and three    days to dose the watertable and    inoculate the entire population.
We might be able to do the same    thing here.
All right... it's worth a try.   But we can't risk the Jem'Hadar    detecting the runabout.       I'll take it to the Jenkata   Nebula...
Come back for us in a week. With    any luck, we'll have a cure by then.
I'm sorry I don't have more space    to offer you.
Don't be. This is fine.       Can I use this table for my    equipment?
Whatever you need.
Did you do this?
My husband did. He died last    winter.

It's what he imagined our world    used to be like. He painted a    mural similar to it on the side of    a building near here.       He traded a good pair of boots for    the paint he needed.       He wanted to show people how    things were, he thought it might   give them something to work    toward...
Maybe later you could take us to    see it...
All right.
Well... looks like we have    ourselves a clinic.
The first thing I need to do is    run a complete biospectral    analysis on an asymptomatic    individual.
Loosely translated, that means he    needs a volunteer.
Great.       If you'll just have a seat, the    doctor will be with you in a    moment.
They love to keep you waiting, it    makes them feel important.
There it is.
Let me see.
What's happened?
We've isolated the virus.
Is that a good thing?
It means we can start analyzing    its molecular structure, look for    binding sites so we can tailor an    antigen.
(translating for Ekoria     with a smile)   It's a very good thing.
I'm going to start mapping the    nucleotides. Do you know how to    run a protein sequencer?
I think so.
I hope you two are hungry.
Starving.
Good.
Looks like a feast.
It was supposed to be.
What do you mean?
Nothing. Do you like Takana root    tea?
Ekoria, where did you get all this    food?
I've been saving it for the    hospital... for my death.
Something tells me I'm not going    to need it anymore...
She's not interested either.
I don't understand why you need    people who've quickened to make    your cure.
I need to study the progression of    the--
Sorry...
You're still here.
Yes.
I see the Blight has spared you.    Maybe it doesn't like the taste of    your blood.
It seems to like yours.
I'd invite you to my death, but we   don't know each other that well.
What if I told you there was a   chance you didn't have to die?
I'm a doctor.
Don't tell me... you have a cure.
I'm working on one.
What will it cost me? A good   coat? A tilo of oil?
It won't cost you anything.
He can help us. Listen to him.
I need volunteers, people who've   quickened.
What will you do? See how loud we    scream as the Blight burns through    us?
I have medicines that dull pain;    I have equipment unlike anything    on your world.
How'd you like me to fix that arm    so you can go play with your friends?
I'm not going to hurt you...
You've got a fracture right here.    I'll bet it hurts.
How's it feel now?
It isn't possible...
It is. You saw it. He can find    a cure for us. But he needs our    help.
Fixing a broken bone and curing    the Blight are two different    things.
I know that.

Others have come to our city with    promises of a cure. They stirred    up hope... took food and clothes    in exchange for their elixirs,    then moved on.       But their promises were always    lies.
And the poor wretches who believed    in them always came to me in the    end, begging for release...
I just want to do what I can to    help. I'm not making any    promises.

Take care that you don't. Because    we've dealt with those who give    false hope before. Wherever    they'd moved on to, we found    them...       And believe me, their deaths made    the Blight look like a blessing...
What's wrong?
I'm trying to chart the life-cycle    of the virus.       It would be a lot easier if I'd    gotten more tissue samples...
Maybe you should go home. Maybe    my people don't deserve your help.
They've just been suffering so    long they've lost hope that things    can be better.
It's more than that. We've come    to... worship death.
I used to wake up --       -- look at myself in that mirror,   and be disappointed that I hadn't   quickened in my sleep.
Going to Trevean seemed so much    easier than going on living.
But you don't feel that way    anymore...
Not since the baby...
My little boy... I wonder, can    your machines tell me what he's    going to look like when he grows    up?
Not really...
Maybe he'll look like his    father...
I want to be here for him... to    hold his hand when he takes his    first step... kiss his knee when    he scrapes it in a fall...
With any luck, you'll see him have    children of his own...
There are some people here who    want to see you...
I suppose you're going to want to    bleed me?
Just a little.
I canceled my death for you... I    was really looking forward to it.
All right, everyone gets three   milligrams, including you.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: Perfect.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: There... this'll dull the pain.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: I like your spots.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: You told me that yesterday.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: I still like them.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: Epran has stopped responding to   the cordrazine... I had to put him   in an inhibitor field.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: He's farther along than anyone    here. But I'm hoping he'll be the    first to respond to the antigen.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: Think of it... she might very well    be holding the cure in her hand.    Do you think we should tell her    what she's giving them?
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: She's nervous enough about using    that hypo. It's better to wait    till we're positive.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: I suppose.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: Why don't you take a break?    You've been working nonstop for    days.
scene: 21   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - DAYS LATER - DUSK

quote: Dax wanted me to tell you that    Epran's white blood cell count has    gone up another twelve percent.
That's great news.
It is?
Trust me.
I do. He turns and sees the admiring look on her face...
I did from the start. I don't    really know why.
I'd like to think it's my bedside    manner...       Doctors and nurses are supposed to    project an air of caring    competence.       You were doing it in there.
Me?
I've been watching you. You're    very good with the patients.
I'm just trying to be kind.
A lot of people don't want to be    around the sick. It reminds them    of their own mortality.
It doesn't bother you?
Sometimes... but I think I'd    rather confront mortality than    hide from it. When you make    someone well, it's like you're   chasing Death off, making him wait    for another day.
But Death comes to everyone in the    end.
Not to Kukalaka.
Kuka-who?
My first patient. A teddy bear.
What's that?

Sort of a soft puppet, stuffed    with wadded cotton. When I was a    boy, I took him everywhere I went.    After a few years, he started to    get a little threadbare, until one    day his leg tore open and his    insides spilled out and made a    mess. My mother was all set to    throw him out, but I wouldn't have    it. At the tender age of five, I    performed my first surgery. I re-   stuffed him, and stitched his leg    closed. From then on, I did    whatever it took to keep Kukalaka    together. I must've sewn,    stitched or patched every square    inch of him.
Why were you so determined to keep    him in one piece?
I wouldn't be much of a doctor if    I gave up on a patient, would I?
Where's Kukalaka now?
Some closet somewhere...
On a shelf in my room...
Julian.
Get in here, now.
Something's causing the virus to    mutate...
Could it be a reaction to the    antigen?
I don't see how -- I need a micro-   cellular scanner.
Bashir...
He'll take care of you... you're    going to be all right...
My god... it's the EM fields from    our instruments.
Shut everything down -- now!
All right, everything's off.
The mutation rate hasn't slowed...    the effect must be cumulative...
Help me...
Give everyone four milligrams of    cordrazine...
His heart's stopped!
Come on... breathe...
Breathe.
Julian...
Julian.
What have you done?
Help me...
Trevean, please...
Get out of my way!
Trevean...
She's asking for me! You have no    right to interfere!
Thank you...
I remember running a hematology    scan on Epran the other day...    there were changes in the viral    base-pair sequence, and I didn't    know why...
There's no way you could've known    it was because of our instruments.
I should've put it together... I    should've run more tests. But I    was so bent on finding a cure I    ignored the warning signs.
That's not fair and you know it.

Isn't it?       I'm going to let you in on a    little secret, Jadzia. I was    looking forward to tomorrow: to    seeing Kira again and casually    asking, "how was the Nebula?"    By the way, I cured that Blight    thing those people were having.
It's not a crime to believe in    yourself, Julian.
They believed in me. Look what it    got them.
Trevean was right... there is no    cure... the Dominion made sure of    that.       But I was so arrogant, I thought    I could find one in a week...
Maybe it was arrogant to think    that. But it's even more arrogant    to think there isn't a cure just    because you couldn't find it.
I'm glad you got a chance to see    it before you left.
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: Ekoria...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: I thought I was going to make    it... I really did...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: I'm sorry...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: Don't be... you gave me hope. I    hadn't felt that since my husband    died...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: I'm going to see Trevean    tomorrow... I wish you could be    there...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: I have to go...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: I understand...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: Good-bye...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: Ekoria, wait...
scene: 32   EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CITY - DAY

quote: Are you sure about this?
I can't leave these people... not    now.
Whenever you're ready, contact the    station and we'll have a runabout    here within days.
You know what really worries me,    Julian... ?       That without me, you won't have    anyone to translate for you...
Good luck...
What is it?
There's not a trace of the antigen   I gave you in your bloodstream...    (unable to figure out     why)   Your immune system must've    rejected it...
Is it bad?
I can give you another hypo, but    you've got a lot of cordrazine in    your system already. It might be   hard on the baby's metabolism.
I'll wait...
What is that smell?
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: I'm making a salve for your    lesions...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: As long as I don't have to drink    it...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: How do you feel?
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: I've been better...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: Can you sit up for me?
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: Breathe...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: Again...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: Let's see how the baby's doing...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: His head's over here now...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: I'm not surprised... feels like    he's been turning somersaults in    there...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: His heart's getting stronger every    day... I'd say another six    weeks...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: I'll never make it that long...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: I can induce labor in another two   weeks... the baby will be old   enough then.
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: Two weeks...
scene: 38   INT. TENEMENT HOUSE - CLOSE ON A BEAKER - DAY

quote: Trevean...       Am I... dead?
Is that what you want?
I can end your suffering...
Your child will die having known    nothing but peace...
No... he deserves a chance to    live...
The Blight will take him in the    end.
I thought you let people come    to you...
I didn't realize you made house    calls.
I was concerned that she might be    too weak to come.
I don't understand why you're so    obsessed with death, Trevean.    From what I've seen, you've lived    with the Blight longer than anyone else.
Yes... and I've seen more    suffering than anyone else.
Good-bye, Ekoria... I hope you    live to see your baby...
Trevean means well... he's a kind    man, in his own way...
That's it... push.
Good... now breathe...
I can see his head. I'm going to    turn it around... gather your    strength for one last push...
Ekoria...
He's beautiful...
My god...
He doesn't have any lesions...       The antigen must've been absorbed   through the placenta... he doesn't   have the Blight...
It's a miracle...
I see that I misjudged you...
Every pregnant woman should be    inoculated as soon as possible...    the antigen will protect their    babies...
I'll see that it's done...
Ekoria had no family left...
I'd be happy to raise her son as    my own...
I think she'd have liked that...
Nucleotide sequencing complete...    viral reproduction normal.
Let's try an A-to-C base pair    reshuffling...
Doctor...
I read your report.
Good work.
Thank you, sir.
Nucleotide sequencing complete...    viral reproduction normal...
People are still dying back there.
Yes... but their children won't.
That's what I keep telling    myself...
Initiate reshuffling sequence...
